conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source, and their shape and size are influenced by the position and distance of the light source relative to the object and the surface where the shadow is cast.
In the initial image, the light source is forward, casting elongated shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
When the light source moves backward, it becomes more directly overhead relative to the objects.
As the light moves back, the shadows will shift closer to the objects themselves because the light rays hit the objects at a steeper angle.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move nearer to their respective objects.
The shadows will become smaller because the light is coming from a higher angle, reducing the elongation.
Shadows will be more compact and closely resemble the shape of the objects.
The shapes of the shadows will become more defined and less stretched out, aligning more directly under the objects.
Shadow A moves closer to the object, becomes shorter and more compact.
Shadow B moves closer to the object, becomes rounder and smaller.
Shadow C moves directly under the object, becomes smaller and more defined.
Shadow D moves closer to the object, becomes smaller with sharper edges.
When the light source moves backward, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to their respective objects and decrease in size, becoming more compact and defined.
